summary: the novel avian influenza viruses and the MERS coronavirus are associated with high mortality rates of over 30%. early detection is also important for infection control and public health measures. sputum was negative in 25% of adult patients with sputum positive for respiratory viruses. many patients do not have sputum production or cannot expectorate good quality sputum. saliva is rarely used for the detection of respiratory viruses because it is generally considered to have inferior sensitivity compared with other respiratory tract specimens. the current study was designed to enable the easy application of our saliva specimen collection method to any clinical setting. participants provided saliva specimens by simple expectoration into a sterile bottle without using special collection devices. written informed consent was obtained from all study participants. aRoutine clinical testing was performed using antigen detection by the DFA. bPatients whose NPA specimens either
